questions.text: All of the following are the systemic conditions associated with keratoconus except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Congenital Syphilis Congenital syphilis is not associated with keratoconus. Congenital syphilis is associated with interstitial keratitis (syphilitic interstitial keratitis). Keratoconus is associated with: Marfan’s syndrome Osteogenesis imperfecta Ehlers Danlos syndrome Asthma Atopy Downs syndrome Mitral valve prolapse

Highyeild:

Associations of keratoconus Keratoconus may be associated with: Ocular conditions , e.g., ectopia lentis, congenital cataract, aniridia, retinitis pigmentosa, vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC), atopic keratoconjunctivitis, Leber's congenital amaurosis, floppy eyelid syndrome, and corneal endothelial dystrophy. Systemic conditions, g., Marfan's syndrome, atopy, asthma, eczema, hay fever. Down's syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, osteogenesis imperfecta, and mitral valve prolapse.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Marfan’s syndrome: associated with keratoconus. Option: C. Osteogenesis imperfecta: associated with keratoconus. Option: D. Ehlers Danlos syndrome: associated with keratoconus.

Extraedge:

KERATOCONUS Non-inflammatory corneal ectasia Conical protrusion of a part of cornea Associated with thinning. It is bilateral but asymmetncal Frequent change of refraction It presents in the adolescent age group Irregular myopic astigmatism is seen. Scissoring Reflex is seen on retinoscopy. Fine vertical folds (Vogt's striae) are seen Prominent corneal nerves are seen Fleischer's ring is seen due to iron deposition Munson's sign Corneal topography is used for confirmation of the diagnosis. Associations ● Down's syndrome • Vernal Catarrh ● Tumer's syndrome. • Blue sclera ● Marfan's syndrome • Retinitis pigmentosa ● Ehler-Danlos syndrome. • Osteogenesis imperfecta Treatment Spectacles followed by rigid gas permeable contact lenses. Collagen cross linking (C3R) Keratoplasty is done in advanced cases.

questions.text: The vertical striations in the cornea as shown in the Image are seen in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Keratoconus

Highyeild:

KERATOCONUS Keratoconus is an AD genetic condition It is non-inflammatory B/L conical ectasia of the cornea associated with progressive high myopia and irregular astigmatism. seen commonly in young males Presents with BOV, DOV, and uniocular polyopia Signs - Oil droplet reflex on DDO Fleischer's ring at the base of the cone due to iron deposition ( iron oxide ) Munson's sign is a localized bulging of the lower eyelid when the patient looks downward . Scissor reflex on retinoscopy Rizutti sign is corneal reflection on the nasal cornea when a penlight shone from the temporal side Vogt's striae is vertical striation on slit lamp Complications: acute hydrops due to rupture of Descemet's membrane Rx- Rigid contact lenses Penetrating keratoplasty TOC- collagen cross linking by riboflavin and UVA to arrest progression

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option:A. Keratitis: features like pain, photophobia, discharge are prominent. Option:C. Keratoconjunctivitis: usually presents with redness, watering or discharge, photophobia and follicles and papillae over the conjunctiva. Option:D. Keratomalacia: Keratomalacia is an eye disorder that involves the drying and clouding of the cornea (the clear layer in front of the iris and pupil) due to vitamin A deficiency.

questions.text: Identify the pathology depicted in the given Image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Keratoconus Munson's sign is a localized bulging of the lower eyelid when the patient looks down.

Highyeild:

Keratoconus Keratoconus is an AD condition. It is a non-inflammatory B/L conical ectasia of the cornea associated with progressive high myopia and irregular astigmatism. seen commonly in young males Presents with BOV, DOV, and uniocular polyopia Signs - Oil droplet reflex on DDO Fleischer's ring at the base of the cone due to iron deposition (iron oxide) Munson's sign is a localized bulging of the lower eyelid when the patient looks ok downward gaze Scissor reflex on retinoscopy Rizutti sign is corneal reflection on the nasal cornea when a penlight shone from the temporal side Vogt's striae is vertical striation on a slit lamp. Complications: acute hydrops due to rupture of Descemet's membrane Rx- Rigid contact lenses Penetrating keratoplasty TOC- collagen cross linking by riboflavin and UVA to arrest progression

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Stye: localised : A stie is a bacterial infection involving one or more of the small glands near the base of your eyelashes . It is similar to a boil or a pimple and is often painful. A stye (sty) is a red, painful lump near the edge of your eyelid that may look like a boil or a pimple. Styes are often filled with pus. Option: B. Conjunctivitis: Inflammation or infection of the outer membrane of the eyeball and the inner eyelid . Conjunctivitis, or pink eye , is an irritation or inflammation of the conjunctiva, which covers the white part of the eyeball. It can be caused by allergies or a bacterial or viral infection. Option: D. Hypopyon corneal ulcer: seen in severe corneal ulcers, behcet’s disease, uveitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the given Image:

options.label: A
options.text: It is also known as Avellino corneal dystrophy

options.label: B
options.text: Generally occurs in 5th decade of life

questions.correct_answer: B. Generally occurs in 5th decade of life
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Generally occurs in 5th decade of life The given Image is granular corneal dystrophy type It generally occurs within the 1st decade of life, as early as 3 years.

Highyeild:

Granular corneal dystrophy, Type 2 (Granular-Lattice) (GCD2) Onset and course. Granular corneal dystrophy, Type 2 (granular-lattice), (GCD2) also known as combined granular-lattice corneal dystrophy or Avellino corneal dystrophy , occurs in the first decade, may be as early as 3 years of age, and is generally progressive . Genetic locus is 5q31 and the gene involved is TGFBl. Inheritance is autosomal dominant. Signs include: • Subtle superficial stromal tiny whitish dots are the initial lesions. Rings or stellate-shaped snowflake stromal opacities appearing between the superficial stroma and the mid stroma are next lesions . Lattice lines in deeper cornea may be seen in some patients. Typically, these lines are the located deeper than the snowflake stromal opacity. Superficial, translucent flattened breadcrumb opacities Symptoms include: Vision decreases with age as the central visual axis becomes affected. Pain and ocular discomfort may accompany mild corneal erosions.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. It is also known as Avellino corneal dystrophy: Granular corneal dystrophy, Type 2 (Granular-Lattice) (GCD2) also known as combined granular-lattice corneal dystrophy or Avellino corneal dystrophy Option: C. It is autosomal dominant: Genetic locus is 5q31 and the gene involved is TGFBl. Inheritance is autosomal dominant. Option: D. Gene involved is TGFB1: correct statement

questions.text: Iridocorneal Endothelial Syndrome (ICE) syndrome is a unique ophthalmic disorder that involves an irregular corneal endothelium and can lead to varying degrees of symptoms. All of the following may be considered part of the iridocorneal endothelial (ICE) syndrome, except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Posterior embryotoxon Iridocorneal endothelial syndrome is a spectrum of diseases including progressive (essential) iris atrophy, Chandler syndrome, and Cogan-Reese syndrome (iris-nevus syndrome). Posterior embryotoxon is an anterior displacement of the Schwalbe line and is not related to this syndrome. All are characterized by a “hammered silver" appearance to the corneal endothelium and varying degrees of iris changes, such as correctopia, holes, and atrophy. Posterior polymorphous dystrophy of the cornea is considered by some to be related to the ICE syndrome.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Chandler syndrome typically has more severe corneal edema than the others and is a part of the spectrum of Iridocorneal endothelial syndrome. Option: B. Essential iris atrophy is associated with polycoria and iris stretch holes and is a part of the spectrum of Iridocorneal endothelial syndrome. Option: C. Cogan-Reese syndrome is characterized by numerous small pigmented nodules, iris atrophy, and pupillary distortion and is a part of the spectrum of Iridocorneal endothelial syndrome.

questions.text: Corneal dystrophies are a group of opacifying disorders that are associated with symptoms like discomfort in the eyes and the decrease in vision. Which of the following among the options given below is not true about corneal dystrophies?

options.label: D
options.text: It mainly affects a particular layer of cornea.

questions.correct_answer: B. They are an inflammatory condition
questions.explanation:
Solution:

They are an inflammatory condition Corneal dystrophies are generally a noninflammatory disorders of the cornea. (Not Inflammatory) Corneal dystrophies are a set of slowly progressive noninflammatory disorders of the cornea that are generally bilateral and also nonvascularized . They are usually associated with symptoms like discomfort in the eyes and a decrease in vision. These opacities mainly affect a particular layer of the cornea . Based on the findings like microscopic and histopathological findings, these dystrophies are classified into I. Epithelial and Subepithelial Dystrophies II. Bowman Layer Dystrophies III. Stromal Corneal Dystrophies IV. Endothelial Corneal Dystrophies

Highyeild:

CORNEAL DYSTROPHIES Corneal dystrophy refers to a group of disorders characterized by the non-inflammatory, inherited, bilateral opacity of the cornea with no vascularisation. In corneal dystrophies, the cells have some inborn defects due to which pathological changes may occur with the passage of time, leading to the development of corneal haze in otherwise normal eyes that are free from inflammation or vascularization. There is no associated systemic disease. Dystrophies occur bilaterally, manifesting occasionally at birth, but more usually during the first or second decade and sometimes even later in life. Epithelial/Subepithelial Epithelial basement membrane dystrophy Bowman's layer Stromal Descemet's membrane / Endothelial Epithelial recurrent erosion dystrophy Meesman dystrophy Lisch epithelial dystrophy Gelatinous drop like dystrophy Bowman's layer Reis Buckler dystrophy Thiel Behnke dystrophy Stromal Lattice dystrophy Granular dystrophy Macular dystrophy Schnyder crystalline dystrophy Central cloudy dystrophy of Francois Descemet's membrane / Endothelial Fuchs endothelial dystrophy Posterior polymorphous dystrophy Congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy X linked endothelial dystrophy Epithelial basement membrane dystrophy is the most common anterior corneal dystrophy . Lattice dystrophy is the most common stromal corneal dystrophy (lattice type I is the commonest type dystrophy ). Fuchs endothelial dystrophy is the most common posterior dystrophy .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . Corneal dystrophies are usually Bilateral Option: C. These opacities are nonvascularized Option: D . It mainly affects a particular layer of cornea.

questions.text: Epithelial dystrophies are those involving the anteriormost layer, which may be asymptomatic or be accompanied by symptoms like pain, diminution of vision, or Lacrimation. Below are a few prominent examples of dystrophies. Which of the following options are not an example of Epithelial type of dystrophy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thiel - Behnke Corneal Dystrophy Thiel - Behnke Corneal Dystrophy is an example of Bowman Layer Type of Dystrophy (Not Epithelial Dystrophy) Some Examples of Epithelial Corneal Dystrophy include: I. Cogan's Microcystic Epithelial Dystrophy II. Epithelial Basement Membrane Dystrophy III. Meesmann Corneal Dystrophy (Juvenile Hereditary Epithelial Dystrophy) IV. Gelatinous Drop Like Corneal Dystrophy V. Lisch Epithelial Corneal Dystrophy

Highyeild:

Epithelial/Subepithelial Epithelial basement membrane dystrophy Bowman's layer Stromal Descemet's membrane / Endothelial Epithelial recurrent erosion dystrophy Meesman dystrophy Lisch epithelial dystrophy Gelatinous drop like dystrophy Bowman's layer Reis Buckler dystrophy Thiel Behnke dystrophy Stromal Lattice dystrophy Granular dystrophy Macular dystrophy Schnyder crystalline dystrophy Central cloudy dystrophy of Francois Descemet's membrane / Endothelial Fuchs endothelial dystrophy Posterior polymorphous dystrophy Congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy X linked endothelial dystrophy Cogans map like Epithelial Dystrophy Meesmann Corneal Dystrophy Lisch Epithelial Corneal Dystrophy Gelatinous Drop Like Corneal Dystrophy

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . Cogan Microcystic Epithelial Dystrophy- Epithelial Dystrophy Option: B . Meesmann Corneal Dystrophy- Epithelial Dystrophy Option: C . Gelatinous Drop Like Corneal Dystrophy- Epithelial Dystrophy

questions.text: Below are some of the characteristic features of some prominent corneal dystrophies. Which of the following options is correct and matches the description with its respective type of dystrophies? May be asymptomatic or recurrent erosions in either a dot -like, map -like, or fingerprint pattern Tiny intraepithelial cysts that are of the same size but different densities, with the highest in the centre grayish white opacities distributed in a geographic manner and also reduced sensation of the cornea Honeycomb like network or Tiny rings like Pattern involving the central part of cornea mainly Select the correct answer from the given below code:

options.label: A
options.text: I - Cogan's Epithelial Dystrophy, II - Meesmann Epithelial Dystrophy, III - Reis- Buckler Corneal Dystrophy, IV - Thiel - Behnke Corneal Dystrophy

options.label: B
options.text: I - Cogan's Epithelial Dystrophy, II - Meesmann Epithelial Dystrophy, III -Thiel - Behnke Corneal Dystrophy, IV - Reis- Buckler Corneal Dystrophy

options.label: C
options.text: I - Meesmann Epithelial Dystrophy, II - Cogan's Epithelial Dystrophy, III - Reis- Buckler Corneal Dystrophy, IV - Thiel - Behnke Corneal Dystrophy

options.label: D
options.text: I - Meesmann Epithelial Dystrophy, II - Cogan's Epithelial Dystrophy, III -Thiel - Behnke Corneal Dystrophy, IV - Reis- Buckler Corneal Dystrophy

questions.correct_answer: A. I - Cogan's Epithelial Dystrophy, II - Meesmann Epithelial Dystrophy, III - Reis- Buckler Corneal Dystrophy, IV - Thiel - Behnke Corneal Dystrophy
questions.explanation:
Solution:

I - Cogan's Epithelial Dystrophy, II - Meesmann Epithelial Dystrophy, III - Reis- Buckler Corneal Dystrophy, IV - Thiel - Behnke Corneal Dystrophy I - Cogan's Epithelial Dystrophy, II - Meesmann Epithelial Dystrophy, III - Reis- Buckler Corneal Dystrophy, IV - Thiel - Behnke Corneal Dystrophy. Cogan's Epithelial Dystrophy often affects the elderly. It may be asymptomatic or present as Recurrent erosions in either a dot like, map like or fingerprint Pattern. Meesmann Epithelial Dystrophy presents as many tiny intraepithelial cysts that are of same size but different densities with highest in the centre. However it does not reach till the Limbus. Corneal sensation is usually reduced and the cornea becomes thin. Reis Buckler Corneal Dystrophy presents as Grayish white opacities distributed in a Geographic manner. The density is seen to increase as Age goes by. The sensation in the cornea is also reduced. Thiel Behnke Corneal Dystrophy presents as a Honeycomb like network or Tiny rings like Pattern involving the central part of cornea mainly.

Highyeild:

Epithelial and subepithelial dystrophies Epithelial basement membrane dystrophy (EBMD)/ COGAN’S SYNDROME Epithelial recurrent erosion dystrophy (ERED). Subepithelial mucinous corneal dystrophy (SMCD). Mutation in keratin genes: Meesmann corneal dystrophy (MECD). Lisch epithelial corneal dystrophy (LECD). Gelatinous drop-like corneal dystrophy (GOLD). Epithelial/Subepithelial Epithelial basement membrane dystrophy Bowman's layer Stromal Descemet's membrane / Endothelial Epithelial recurrent erosion dystrophy Meesman dystrophy Lisch epithelial dystrophy Gelatinous drop like dystrophy Bowman's layer Reis Buckler dystrophy Thiel Behnke dystrophy Stromal Lattice dystrophy Granular dystrophy Macular dystrophy Schnyder crystalline dystrophy Central cloudy dystrophy of Francois Descemet's membrane / Endothelial Fuchs endothelial dystrophy Posterior polymorphous dystrophy Congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy X linked endothelial dystrophy Epithelial Basement Membrane Dystrophy/Cogan microcystic epithelial dystrophy: Epithelial basement membrane dystrophy (EBMD) is also known as map-dot-fingerprint dystrophy, Cogan microcystic epithelial dystrophy, or anterior basement membrane dystrophy . . Genetic locus and gene are 5q 3-1 and TGFP-l, respectively. Onset, course, and symptoms present in adult life, rarely seen in children. Asymptomatic or recurrent erosions with pain, lacrimation, and blurred vision are observed. Signs. Typical lesions include : Maps : Irregular islands of thickened, grey, hazy epithelium with scalloped, circumscribed borders, particularly affecting the central or paracentral cornea .Isolated or combined with other signs. Dots (Cogan). Irregular round, oval, non -staining, putty-grey opacities. Fingerprint lines. Parallel, curvilinear lines, usually paracentral, best seen in retroillumination. They may be isolated or combined with other signs, especially maps. Bleb pattern (Bron). A subepithelial pattern like pebbled glass, best seen by retroillumination. Isolated or combined with other signs. Cogans Epithelial Dystrophy Meesmann Epithelial Dystrophy Reis Buckler Corneal Dystrophy Thiel Behnke Corneal Dystrophy

questions.text: A 17-year-old teenage boy came to the Ophthalmology department with blurring of vision which was progressively worsening. He also complained of photophobia and Glare. The Following image was obtained. On seeing the following image, the ophthalmologist suspected it to be a granular type of stromal corneal dystrophy. Which of the following statements about the diagnosis is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: On histology, bright red colour is observed when stained with Masson trichrome

options.label: B
options.text: There is whitish central deposits/opacities with a clear background of stroma

options.label: C
options.text: The Corneal margin is always affected

questions.correct_answer: C. The Corneal margin is always affected
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The Corneal margin is always affected The corneal margin, or limbus is rarely affected in granular corneal dystrophy. The clinical vignette along with the given image helps to come to a diagnosis of granular corneal dystrophy. It has an autosomal dominant type of inheritance which, usually affects during the time of puberty.

Highyeild:

STROMAL CORNEAL DYSTROPHIES TGFB l Corneal Dystrophies These include: lattice corneal dystrophy , which is of two types: Classic lattice corneal dystrophy(LCD1) Lattice corneal dystrophy, gelsolin rype (LCD2) Granular corneal dystrophy , which is of three types: Granular corneal dystrophy, type l (classic) (GCDl) Granular corneal dystrophy, type 2 (granular lattice) (GCD2) Granular corneal dystrophy, type 3 (GCD3). Granular corneal dystrophy, Type 1 (classic) (GCDI) Onset and course . Granular corneal dystrophy, Type 1 (Classic) (GCD 1), also known as Corneal dystrophy Groenouw type 1 occurs in childhood, may be seen as early as 2 years of age. As the condition progresses, the opacities become more confluent in the superficial cornea.The genetic locus is 5q3 l and the gene involved in TGF B 1 . Inheritance is autosomal dominant . Signs: The condition is ch:aracterised by milky granular hyaline deposits in anterior stroma. Intervening stroma is clear. Opacities do not extend to the limbus. In children, there may be a vortex pattern of brownish granules superficial to the Bowman layer. In later life, granules may extend into the deeper stroma, down to the Descemet membrane. Symptoms include: • Glare and photophobia are early symptoms. • Recurrent erosions occur frequently, causing ocular discomfort, pain, and watering. • Visual acuity decreases as opacification progresses with age.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option; A. histology section of this dystrophy shows amorphous deposits of hyaline, bright red in colour when it is stained with Masson trichrome. Given below is the histology section of Granular Corneal dystrophy. Option: B. There is whitish central deposits/opacities with a clear background of stroma The presenting complaints include glare, photophobia, and diminution of vision. Option: D. Management is done by penetrating keratoplasty.

questions.text: Stromal Corneal Dystrophies occur during puberty which slowly progresses as age goes by. Various types of stromal Corneal dystrophies have distinct histological findings. Match the following histological findings with the type of stromal Corneal dystrophy given below: Amyloid Deposits are observed when stained with Congo red. A green birefringence observed in polarized light Hyaline deposits which shows a bright red colour when stained with Masson Trichrome GAG accumulates in and out of the cell. Stains used are Alcian Blue and Colloidal Iron. Select the correct answer from the given below code:

options.label: A
options.text: I - Granular, II - Lattice, III - Macular

options.label: B
options.text: I - Lattice, II - Granular, III - Macular

options.label: C
options.text: I - Lattice, II - Macular, III - Granular

options.label: D
options.text: I - Macular, II - Granular, III – Lattice

questions.correct_answer: B. I - Lattice, II - Granular, III - Macular
questions.explanation:
Solution:

I - Lattice, II - Granular, III - Macular I - Lattice Corneal Dystrophy II - Granular Corneal Dystrophy III - Macular Corneal Dystrophy Histology findings of various stromal Corneal dystrophies are as followed Lattice Corneal Dystrophy - Amyloid Deposits are observed when stained with Congo red . A green birefringence observed in polarized light. Granular Corneal Dystrophy - Hyaline deposits which shows a bright red colour when stained with Masson Trichrome Macular Corneal Dystrophy - Glycosaminoglycans accumulate in and out of the cell. Stains used are Alcian Blue and Colloidal Iron.

questions.text: A middle aged woman who came to the Ophthalmology OPD with complaints of diminution of vision in both eyes which is progressive gradually. She also mentions that it is more in the morning. After all the relevant investigations, the ophthalmologist suspects it to be Fuchs endothelial dystrophy. Which of the treatment options given below is not true for this diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: NaCl 5% topically and IOP reduction are the conservative management options

options.label: B
options.text: Hair dryer can be used to keep the cornea dehydrated

options.label: C
options.text: Bandage contact lens, lubricants, cycloplegics for ruptured bullae

questions.correct_answer: D. Keratoplasty is usually not recommended
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Keratoplasty is usually not recommended Keratoplasties like penetrating keratoplasty or posterior lamellar keratoplasty are recommended management options. Keratoplasty is the recommended surgical management option. Descemet's Membrane Keratoplasty, Post. Lamellar Keratoplasty, or Penetrating Keratoplasty are usually used. Conjunctival flaps, amniotic membrane transplantation for patients whose visual potential is very poor. Rho kinase inhibitors is a recent advanced development that helps in the proliferation of endothelial cells.

Highyeild:

Fuchs Endothelial Dystrophy Fuchs Endothelial Corneal Dystrophy Onset and course Fuchs endothelial corneal dystrophy {FECD), also known as endothelial corneal dystrophy, is frequently seen as a slowly progressive bilateral condition affecting females more than males {F:M::4: 1), usually between fifth and seventh decade of life. Primary open angle glaucoma is its common association. Inheritance It may be autosomal dominant or sporadic (more common) in nature. genetic locus is 13p. No gene has been associated. Clinical features can be divided into following four stages: Stage of cornea guttata . It is characterised by the presence of Hassall-Henle type of excrescences in the central part of cornea. A gradual increase of central guttae with peripheral spread and confluence gives rise to the so-called 'beaten-metal' appearance. This stage is asymptomatic. Oedematous stage or stage of endothelial decompensation is characterised by the occurrence of early stromal oedema and epithelial dystrophy. Patients complain of blurring vision. Stage of bullous keratopathy . This stage follows longstanding stromal oedema and is characterised by marked epithelial oedema with formation of bullae, when rupture causes pain, discomfort and irritation with associated decreased visual acuity. Stage of scarring . In this stage, epithelial bullae are replaced by scar tissue and the cornea becomes opaque and vascularized. The condition may sometimes be complicated by occurrence of secondary infection or glaucoma. Specular microscopy reveals decreased endothelial cell count, increased average cell diameter, decreased hexagons and increased variation in cell size. Treatment is as follows : Hypertonic saline: (5% sodium chloride ) may be of some use in the early edematous stage. Warm air blown on the eyes (e.ghair dryer) helps reduce oedema. Intraocular pressure lowering drugs, e.g. 0.5% timolol or others, should be used to treat associated ocular hypertension. Bandaged soft contact lenses provide some relief from disturbing symptoms in the bullous keratopathy stage. Penetrating keratoplasty is the treatment of choice when the visual acuity is reduced markedly.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. NaCl 5% topically as drops or ointment and IOP reduction are the conservative management options. Option: B. Hair dryer can be used to keep the cornea dehydrated. Option: C. Bandage contact lens, lubricants, cycloplegics, antibiotic ointments can be used for ruptured bullae.
